awd_titl_txt: CSR: Medium: Collaborative Research: GridPac: A Resource Management System for Energy and Performance Optimization on Computational Grids
awd_abstract_narration:
Massive energy consumption is an escalating threat to the environment. Large-scale computational grids consume a substantial amount of energy, and 
their energy requirements for powering and cooling are becoming comparable to the costs of acquisition. There is a lack of generally applicable methods for reducing energy consumption while ensuring good quality of service. This project will develop GridPac (Grid with Power-Aware Computing), a middleware environment that will allow grid managers and service providers to schedule multiple workflows across a distributed grid for system-wide optimization. GridPac will be based on a novel framework to support a variety of task-level workflows. The main features of this work are to develop: 

(a) Novel static and dynamic algorithms for scheduling single and multiple workflows, which can be flexibly utilized by service providers in scalable grid environments. 

(b) Control algorithms to account for dynamic adjustment of schedules using energy monitoring of the grid resources. 

(c) Extensive benchmarking using a suite of commonly used grid workflows. 

(d) A prototype middleware to assist IT organizations to better support their users while reducing energy costs. 

The proposed work will lead to original scholarly contributions while harnessing the usage of computational grids. The project carries tremendous potential for economic, environmental, and societal impact. We will initiate new graduate and undergraduate level courses on related topics, and develop relevant tutorials, which will help to create awareness and educate a large audience on a critically important research topic.

por.por_cntn:
Energy is now at the heart of issues pertaining to sustainable computing. In a large-scale computer system, such as a computational grid or a cloud, energy consumption can outweigh the procurement costs. Reducing the energy consumption and stretching the computational task schedule can be a viable option to strike a balance between energy savings, system utilization, and performance. More often than not, the workload has performance requirements, such as task deadlines. The tradeoff of linear degradation in performance results in about a quadratic energy savings applied per task considering the power consumption within the processor. This project investigated and proposed software based automated means of optimizing energy and performance by properly executing application workload. Our techniques utilize the technology now widely built into contemporary processors known as Dynamic Voltage and Frequency Scaling (DVFS), which can ratchet up or down the CPU frequency to properly accommodate the task being executed on a processor. We developed, proposed and compared cooperative and non-cooperative games for the EATA problem on a heterogeneous set of machines. Game theory provides power mathematical tools to solve optimization problems with conflicting goals. We developed several new schemes and published the results in journals and conferences. The first is a cooperative game based approach, improving upon previous work, and the second is a new non-cooperative approach. For the former, a static scheduling algorithm is created and proved axiom by axiom to generate a Nash Bargaining Solution for the EATA problem with energy consumption as the primary objective. For the latter, a static scheduling algorithm is designed to illustrate the lower bound on execution time for a bargaining approach over the EATA problem with energy consumption as the primary objective. The energy savings generated by the proposed algorithms is achieved through DVFS at the processor level. The comparison leads to some new findings and interesting results, highlighting the strength of each scheme in terms of low complexity and superior performance which were the two major objectives. We trained graduate students, organized conferences and also organized other professional activities to disseminate our research findings. In combining mathematical techniques and computer science, our research has pioneered the use of optimization techniques such as game theory for self-management of distributed computing systems for their energy management in a self-controlled and autonomous manner.  We are outreaching to industry and have also been collaborating with DOE's working group on sustainable computing. We will collaborate to create new knowledge, tools and technologies at the component, system, and facility level.  We are also making partnerships with industry leaders such as IBM, Google, Intel, HP and Texas Instruments for knowledge creation and technology transfer. 

 

Our work contributed to the scientific knowledge and have commercialization potential which can contribute sustainability.
